Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Infrastructure Improvement (RII) Track-3 award seeks to engage teachers and students from high schools with high enrollment of underrepresented minority (URM) students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM)-based, project driven experiences. The project aims to develop curricular materials on the engineering design process for adaptation in high schools, and increase the STEM success of African-American and female students by engaging them in competitive hands-on activities. The overall goal of this project is to increase Louisiana's capacity and innovation in STEM fields and develop a sustainable program that can be adopted broadly across the nation.

Intellectual Merit
The STEM-Discovery program establishes university-high school partnerships and facilitates project-based STEM learning in the engineering design process. The project offers summer camps and team competitions that are designed to motivate high school students to understand the fundamentals of engineering design challenges. The program also exposes the students to key enabling technologies and helps them develop teamwork and communication skills. The program is based on the premise that competition drives excellence and provides connections to real-world applications such as designing a fuel-cell car. The project also offers workshops for high school teachers that provide professional development and networking opportunities. The program is structured to test a small scale pilot, refine the program by incorporating participant feedback, and expand to engage more high schools and universities in STEM partnerships.

Broader Impacts
Building on established connections between Louisiana Tech University and high schools, the STEM-Discovery project has identified twelve partnering high schools with high URM student enrollments. Over the five years of the project, at least 84 teachers and 252 students from these high schools will be engaged directly in the workshops and design competitions. Teacher professional development and interaction among students at these schools have the potential to attract non-participating students and stimulate their interest in higher education and careers in STEM-related areas. Broad dissemination of the project content to a larger audience is provided through virtual learning venues and workshops at national professional conferences. The model of empowering underrepresented minority students and teachers in high schools through project-based learning by immersion in content focused camps and design project competitions is potentially scalable and adaptable across the nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The STEM-Discovery program developed and implemented curricula and student competitions throughout the state of Louisiana. The program was modeled after other successful programs created at Louisiana Tech University including Cyber Discovery, LaTechSTEP, NASA-Threads, and Living With the Lab. The program is geared toward Louisiana high schools that have a significant percentage of underrepresented minority groups. The proposed goal of reaching 252 students was far exceeded by directly impacting 614 students through project activities. Additionally, the original proposal targeted 84 teachers, and over the course of the project, 120 teachers were directly impacted. These teachers will ultimately have a much larger impact through the interactions that they have on other students that they teach.  

The early years of the project focused on developing content and delivery through a camp model. This pilot STEM-Discovery camp and competition was held at Louisiana Tech and served to provide feedback on the curricular materials. The pilot camp was a critical part of developing a sustainable model that was used in the final years of the project and going forward.

One of the original goals of the project was to create an outreach program that could be delivered online along with a multi-school competition to be held at the end of the school year. After working with the schools, we found that they regularly provided feedback which suggested that the in-person workshops were a critical part of the program?s success. As we expanded to other areas of the state, the move toward an online delivery model was successful, but feedback from the schools and observations of the project leadership revealed that in-person interaction was still a needed component. Based on this feedback, we implemented ?one-day-builds? to facilitate interaction between participants and project leadership.  

As part of the STEM-Discovery effort, a kit was designed for building a wireless controller and a Remote Control (RC) car. This kit was designed so that basic prototyping tools available in participating schools could be used to fabricate the needed parts. Students were able to understand assembly and fabrication, as well as techniques for rendering the parts. This approach provides participants with a more intuitive and applied understanding to peak their interest in STEM fields. All digital files, instructions, and curriculum resources developed are freely available online.

STEM-Discovery used multiple methods of content delivery including residential camps, online delivery, weekend workshops, and one-day-builds. The project is sustained through a one-day-build approach that culminates in a competition among participants. Funding for four additional years (2020-2023), following the completion of the STEM-Discovery project, has been secured. This allows for the project to be sustained and even expanded to other areas of the state. By working with GearUP schools, which have a high underrepresented minority percentage of students, this project will further reach students beyond the STEM-Discovery funding.

Intellectual Merit :

The STEM-Discovery program created a new high school STEM-related competition and curriculum. These elements are available freely online through a website and allow for asynchronous modules to be used by high school teachers and students. The modules deliver educational content related to engineering design and entrepreneurship.

Broader Impacts :

Materials created as part of the program are available to other institutions for use in their region. Additionally, by working with GearUP schools in the state, the project further impacts students that are underrepresented in the STEM fields.
